meaningMnemonic: Remember how 生まれる means "to be born"? This word is similar, but it's used for when non-living things are "born". So as an intransitive verb, this means <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to arise</vocabulary>. When used transitively, it means <vocabulary>to cause something</vocabulary>. You'll probably encounter the intransitive use much more, though.

You'd think this would use kun'yomi, but it actually doesn't! Like other verbs ending in じる, this takes the on'yomi reading of the kanji. 生 has two of those, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: 

If you wanted anything <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary> in medieval Japan, you needed to talk to the <reading>Shou</reading>gun. You always needed the Shougun's help <vocabulary>to cause something</vocabulary>. Without the Shougun, nothing would ever happen!
